multiply: perform the operation of repeated addition of a number
simplify: to make easier to understand or more concise
calculate: to determine an amount or number using mathematics
probability: a measure of the likelihood that an event will occur
circumference: the enclosing boundary of a curved geometric figure, especially a circle
proof: a logical argument that demonstrates the truth of a statement
radius: a straight line from the centre to the circumference of a circle or sphere
Venn diagram: A diagram that shows all possible logical relations between a finite collection of different sets.
straight line: a linear equation that can be represented by a line on a graph
coordinates: pairs of numbers used to locate a point in a plane
integer: a whole number; a number that is not a fraction or a decimal
graph: A diagram showing the relationship between variables.
pie chart: A graphical representation of data in a circular chart divided into sectors to illustrate numerical proportion
grid: A network of uniformly spaced horizontal and vertical lines used for locating points in a space.
denominator: the bottom number in a fraction
numerator: the top number in a fraction
whole number: a number without fractions or decimals
multiple: A number that can be divided by another number without a remainder
function: A relation between a set of inputs and a set of permissible outputs.
exponent: A quantity representing the power to which a given number or expression is to be raised
expand: to make larger or more extensive
construct: To draw or create a geometric figure.
form: a specific way of arranging or doing something
region: a specified area or section within a larger space
letter: a character representing one or more of the sounds used in speech; any of the symbols of an alphabet
vector: a quantity having direction as well as magnitude, especially as determining the position of one point in space relative to another
scale factor: a number which scales or multiplies the size of a shape
width: the measurement or extent of something from side to side

comment: a statement that expresses a personal opinion or belief about someone
rabbit: a small mammal with long ears
name: åå­—
y-intercept: the point at which the line intersects the y-axis
algebraic expression: a mathematical phrase that can contain numbers, variables, and operation symbols
theorem: a statement that can be proved true using a logical argument
exchange rate: The value of one currency for the purpose of conversion to another.
children: Plural form of child, a young human being below the age of puberty
chart: a sheet of information in the form of a table, graph, or diagram.

quadratic equation: an equation of the form ax^2 + bx + c = 0, where a, b, and c are constants
matrix: a rectangular array of numbers, symbols, or expressions arranged in rows and columns
trigonometry: a branch of mathematics that studies relationships between the sides and angles of triangles
geometry: a branch of mathematics that deals with the properties and relations of points, lines, surfaces, solids, and higher dimensional analogs
mathematical induction: a method of mathematical proof typically used to establish that a given statement is true for all natural numbers
base case: the initial condition in a mathematical induction proof
inductive step: the part of a mathematical induction proof where it is shown that if the statement is true for a particular case, then it is also true for the next case
positive integer: a whole number greater than zero
die: a cube with numbers 1 to 6 on its faces, used in games of chance
event: a subset of the sample space
win: To emerge as the victorious participant in a competition
participant: A person who takes part in a research study or survey.
sampling process: The method used to select a sample from a population for research purposes.
personal viewpoint: An individual's perspective or opinion on a particular matter.
experience: Knowledge or skill acquired over a period of time.
survey: a method of collecting data or information about a group of people
research: Systematic investigation to establish facts and reach new conclusions.
like_terms: Terms in an expression that have the same variables raised to the same power
forecast: predicting future trends based on past data
rabbitry: a place where rabbits are raised or kept
quartiles: The three points that divide a dataset into four equal parts.
(c): An arbitrary constant used in the general solution of differential equations to account for all possible solutions.
precision: the quality of being exact and accurate
knowledge: facts, information, and skills acquired through experience or education
aspect: a particular part or feature of a situation, idea, problem, subject, etc.
numerical value: a number that represents a quantity or measurement
combination: a selection of objects without regard to the order of selection
LCM calculation: The process of finding the smallest common multiple of two or more numbers
coverage: extent to which something is covered
rule: a set way in which things behave or operate
calculus: a branch of mathematics that focuses on rates of change and accumulation of quantities
statistics: the study of the collection, analysis, interpretation, presentation, and organization of data
square number: A number that is the square of an integer
speed-time graph: A graphical representation showing how speed changes over time

males: plural of male, refers to individuals who are men or boys
files: A collection of data or information that is stored electronically.

adjacent angles: Angles that have a common vertex and a common side but do not overlap
experiment: a procedure that can be infinitely repeated and has a well-defined set of possible outcomes

next: Coming immediately after the present one in order, rank, or space.
simplification: reducing an expression or equation to its simplest form by combining like terms or following mathematical rules
shadow region: The shadow region is a term generally used in the context of linear programming or graphing inequalities. It refers to the area on a graph that satisfies all the given inequalities simultaneously, often shaded in a particular way to highlight that region.
magnitude: the great size or extent of something
parameter: a variable that represents a quantity in a mathematical model or formula
box_and_whisker_plot: A box and whisker plot is a graphical representation of the five-number summary of a data set.
electricity bill: a bill detailing the cost of electricity consumed over a specific period of time
Table: A way to organize data into rows and columns for easier reading and analysis
formal: following an established form or procedure
union: The set containing all elements that are in at least one of the sets being compared.

algebraic operations: Algebraic operations involve manipulating algebraic expressions using arithmetic operations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.
exhibition: a public display or demonstration of skills or work
solar_system: the collection of eight planets and their moons in orbit around the sun
values table: A way to organize values for different variables to show their relationship
attendance: the action or state of going regularly to or being present at a place or event
train: A form of transport consisting of a series of connected vehicles that move along railway tracks, carrying passengers or goods.
coordinate system: A system that uses one or more numbers to uniquely determine the position of a point or other geometric element on a surface
Write: Translate words or symbols into a mathematical expression or equation.
operate: to work or function in a particular way
explanation: a detailed description or reasoning to justify a solution or answer
procedure: set of rules or steps to follow
solution set: the set of values that satisfy the given inequality
number_line: a straight line on which numbers are marked at intervals, used to represent quantities
prime factorisation: Expressing a number as the product of its prime factors
festival: a day or period of celebration
liters: a unit of volume in the metric system
joules: a unit of energy in the International System of Units (SI)
conjecture: a statement that is believed to be true but has not been proven
explicitly: in a clear and detailed manner, leaving no room for confusion or doubt
ordered stem-and-leaf plot: A way of organizing and displaying data where the first digit of each number forms the stem and the second digit forms the leaf.
corollary: a statement that can be easily deduced or inferred from a proven theorem
formulate: To develop or create a mathematical equation or expression.
fourth quartile: the three points Q1, Q2, and Q3 that divide a data set into four equal parts
average rate of change: Mathematical concept to calculate the rate at which one quantity is changing with respect to another
dependent variable: A variable whose value depends on the value of another variable
independent variable: A variable whose value is not dependent on another variables value
scenario: an imagined or projected sequence of events
Tally: A tally is a mark or count symbol used to record frequencies.
divisor: The number by which another number is to be divided.
equation of a straight line: the formula to represent a straight line on a graph
logic: the study of reasoning and inference, or the systematic use of valid reasoning
Box Plot: A graphical representation of the distribution of a dataset based on five summary statistics: minimum, first quartile, median, third quartile, and maximum.
stem-and-leaf plot: A type of data display that shows the distribution of data values in a given set by splitting the values into 'stem' (leading digit(s)) and 'leaf' (last digit)
demonstrate: to show or explain how something is done
mathematical operations: Basic mathematical calculations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.
linear algebra: a branch of mathematics that studies vectors, vector spaces, linear transformations, and systems of linear equations
repeating decimal: A repeating decimal is a decimal number in which a pattern of digits is repeated indefinitely.
cycles: In mathematics, a cycle refers to a repeating pattern or sequence of numbers.
faulty: not functioning correctly or as intended
proper fraction: A proper fraction is a fraction where the numerator is less than the denominator.
combine like terms: to simplify expressions by adding or subtracting terms that have the same variables and exponents
distance formula: a formula used to find the distance between two points in a coordinate plane
Mixed number: a number made up of a whole number and a proper fraction.
Improper fraction: a fraction where the numerator is greater than or equal to the denominator.
Public factors: numbers that are factors of two or more numbers.
supplementary angles: Two angles whose measures add up to 180 degrees
vertical angles: Pairs of opposite angles formed by intersecting lines
area_expression_OPQ: Expression for the OPQ sector area
area_expression_OAB: Expression for the OAB sector area
arc_length_shadow_part: Arc length of the shadow part
resultant: a vector sum of two or more vectors
friend: a person whom one knows and with whom one has a bond of mutual affection, typically exclusive of sexual or family relations

value substitution: Replacing a variable in a mathematical expression with a specific number
context: the circumstances that form the setting for an event
integration: the process of finding the integral of a function, a basic operation in calculus
differentiation: the process of finding a derivative of a function
bill: a statement of money owed for goods or services provided
normal number: a real number that is not a complex number
mathematical error: Sian's error in solving the problem
incorrect solution: Sian's incorrect answer to the problem
non-negative integer: a whole number that is zero or greater
logarithmic identity: the relationship between exponential and logarithmic forms of an expression
exponential expression: a mathematical expression in which a number is raised to a power
tree: A woody perennial plant, typically having a single stem or trunk growing to a considerable height
random_variable: a variable whose possible values are numerical outcomes of a random phenomenon
sample_space: the set of all possible outcomes of a random experiment
probability_distribution: a mathematical function that provides the probabilities of occurrence of different possible outcomes
independent_events: events for which the occurrence of one does not affect the probability of the occurrence of the other
dependent_events: events for which the occurrence of one affects the probability of the occurrence of the other
complementary_event: the complement of an event, representing all outcomes not in the event
mutually_exclusive_events: events that cannot happen at the same time
conditional_probability: the probability of an event given that another event has already occurred
odds: a numerical expression of the likelihood of a particular outcome
permutation: an arrangement of objects in a specific order
expected_value: the long-run average value of repetitions of the experiment it represents
equally_likely_outcomes: outcomes that have an equal chance of occurring
discrete_probability_distribution: a probability distribution characterized by a countable number of outcomes
continuous_probability_distribution: a probability distribution characterized by an infinite number of outcomes
mathematical_expectation: the mean of a probability distribution
bionomial_distribution: a discrete probability distribution of the number of successes in a sequence of independent experiments
increasing function: A function for which each element of the domain has a greater image in the range
decreasing function: A function for which each element of the domain has a lesser image in the range
currency exchange: The act of changing one country's currency into the currency of another country.
banknotes: Paper money issued by a central bank.
ambiguity: a term having more than one meaning
station: A place where trains stop to pick up and drop off passengers.
east: The direction towards the east (usually considered as going clockwise on a compass, 90 degrees from north).
west: The direction towards the west (usually considered as going anticlockwise on a compass, 270 degrees from north).
departure: The action of leaving, especially when starting a journey by train or other means of transport.
morning: The period of time between midnight and noon.
clock: A mechanical or electrical device for measuring time, indicating hours, minutes, and sometimes seconds by hands or numerals on a circular dial.

subject matter: a particular topic or issue that is being discussed, described, or dealt with
linguistic structures: the patterns of words and phrases used in a language
idiomatic expressions: phrases that have a meaning different from the meanings of the individual words in it
grammar rules: specific rules that govern the composition of sentences in a given language
evolving terminology: terminology that is continuously changing and developing over time
concepts: abstract ideas and general notions associated with mathematics and other subjects
educational systems: the structures and methods used by countries to educate their students
terminologies: special terms or expressions used in relation to a particular subject
speak Spanish: communicate or convey thoughts, feelings, or information in the Spanish language
coordinate geometry: the study of geometry using the coordinate plane and algebraic methods
value range: The set of all possible values that a function or variable can take.
